This is an appeal from a decree of the Consul-General at Kashgarh passed under the jurisdiction vested in him by His Majesty the King’s Order-in-Counc il, dated the 11th March 1920, published in the Gazette of India under notification Lo.2058-G, dated the 4th October 1920. The appeal was pre sented to the Consul-General at Kashgarh and was forwarded by him to this Court under the provisions of paras 38 to 41 of the Order-in-Council. in forwarding the appeal His Britannic Majesty’s Consul-General remarked that it was presumed that the necessary Court-fee stamps would be affixed by the appellant or his representative before the appeal was heard. The Bench before whom the appeal first came noted that Court-fees were apparently necessary as the ordinary rules applicable to the High Court seemed to apply and as all that the Order-in-Council did was to give a right of appeal to the High Court. The Bench, however, did not think it desirable finally to decide tte point in question till parties had an opportunity of attending. Parties are now represented by counsel before us and we have heard arguments on the question the Government Advocate also appearing on behalf of the financial Commissioners. Para 8 of the Kashgarh Order-in-Council, 1920, runs as follows:-”(1) Subject to the other provisions of this Order, and. to any Treaties for the time being in force relating to Kashgarh, His Majesty’s criminal and civil jurisdiction within the limits of this Order shall, so far as circumstances admit, be exercised on the principles of, and in conformity with, the enactments for the time being applicable as hereinafter mentioned of the Governor-General of India in Council, and of tte Lieutenant Governor of the Punjab in Council, and in accordance with the powers vested in, and the course of procedure and practice observed by and before, the Courts in the Punjab according to their respective jurisdiction and authority, and, so far as such enactments, powers, procedure, and practice are applicable, shall be exercised in accordance with justice, equity, and good conscience. ” (2) The enactments mentioned in the First Schedule to this order are hereby made applicaole within the limits of this Order as from the commencement of this Orde r”. # * * In the first schedule the Court-fees Act is not mentioned. It is, therefore, not applicable in Kashgarh. Under para 33 the Consul-G-eneral shall be deemed to oe District Judge, and the Court shall be deemed to be the District oourt of Principal ourt of Original Jurisdiction in the district; the .vhie^ (High) Court of the Punjab shall be deemed to be the highest Civil Court of Appeal for the district and the Court authorised to hear appeals from the decisions of the District Court. Paras 38 to 41 allow a person desirous of appealing to present his memorandum of appeal to the Court, i.e. to the Consul-General, and after serving notice and taking written arguments which the parties may desire to submit, the Consul- General is empowered to forward the appeal to this high Court. Lastly in paras 54 and 55 provision is made for framing rules, imposing fees leviable in respect of any proceedings in, or processes issued out of, the Court, Ho such rules, however, have be e n f rame d. Mr. Badri Das on behalf of the appellants contended that no Court-fees need be paid on the memorandum of appeal in this Court as the Court-fees Act is not in force in Kashgarh and the appeal was instituted in Kashgarh by presentation of the memorandum of appeal to Kis Britannic Majesty’s Consul-General underunder para 38 of the Order-in-Council. He also contended that the jurisdiction conferred upon this Court was not under an Indian Statute but under His Majesty’s Order-in-Council, and that, therefore, the Court-fees Act, which was ordinarily applicable to the High Court, did not apply to this extra ordinary jurisdiction. As against this it was contended by the learned Government Advocate that this Court is bound by the provisions of section 4 of the Court-fees Act, especially as there is nothing in tne Kashgar h Orde r-in-Co unc il, 1920, to modify those provisions, so far as they were applicable to this Court. The Government Advocate was able to point out to us a nearly parallel Order-in-Counc il, namely, The Persian Coast and islands Order-in-Council, 1907. The provisions of that Order-in-Counc il are with minor differences the same as those of the Kashgarh Order-in-Counc il, 1920. The a Appellate Court under the 1907 Order-in-Council was, of course, the High Court of Bombay. The Government Advocate informed us that appeals under that Order-in-Council, which has now been cancelled, used to be stamped with full Court-fees in the Bombay Court as a matter of psui practice, though the question of tne legality of the charge never fell to be judicially decided. There is thus no authority on tne question. It seems to me that there can be no escape from the conclusion tteit section 4 of the Court-fees Act applies to all appeals to this Court from Courts subject to its superintendence. By virtue of para 33 of the Order-in-Council this Court is the hig he st Civil Court of Appeal for the Court of the Consul- General, Kashgarh. Under section 107 of the Government of India Act, 1915, each of the High Courts lias superintendence over all Courts for the time being subject to its appellate jurisdiction. It is true that provision is made for instituting the appeal in the Court of the Consul-General and for him to transmit the appeal to the High Court; that however, does not necessarily mean that section 4 of the CourtCourt-fees Act has been repealed. Further, the fact that the Ax Court-fees Act is not in force in Kashgarh does not imply that appeals in this Court from decisions of the Court in Kashgarh also are exempt from Court-fees. In my judgment, Court-fees are payable and I would direct that they be paid within two months. If they are paid, the appeal will be posted for hearing and if not, the appeal should be posted for further orders. Sd/- J.Addison, Judge. I concur. Sd. mods.abstract: Correspondence concerning the payment of court fees within the limits of the China (Kashgar) Order in Council, 1920. The correspondence is between officials at the Government of India (Foreign and Political Department), Foreign Office, the Governments of Bombay and Punjab, the Consul General at Kashgar, and the British Embassy in Peking.The papers include minutes, draft letters, and copies of various legislation. Matters dealt with by the correspondence include:The question of whether Indian court fees are leviable on cases tried in Kashgar, including the amendment to the Kashgar Order in Council to provide for the application of the Indian Court Fees Act, 1870, to KashgarAmendments to the Order in Council to provide for the payment of court fees in rupees, rather than the Kashgar Tael.
